newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech parliament lifts Republican chief's immumity.
newsitem.headline: Czech parliament lifts Republican chief's immumity.

text.p: The Czech parliament voted on Thursday to lift the parliamentary immunity of the head of the ultra-right Republican and two of his party colleagues, opening the way for a possible prosecution.

Deputies in the 200-seat lower house of parliament voted 94 to 66 to approve a request to allow police to investigate alleged anti-German remarks by Miroslav Sladek during a visit to Prague in January by German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, parliament's press department said.
Sladek has been quoted in local media as telling his followers that "we can only regret that we only killed a few Germans during the war". The remarks have been widely quoted, and never denied.

Sladek was reported to have made the statement at a demonstration on January 21 against the signing by Kohl and Czech Prime Minster Vaclav Klaus of a declaration aimed at healing old World War Two wounds.

In the declaration Germany expressed sorrow for the Nazi occupation of the Czech lands and the Czech side apologised for any brutality involved in the post-war expulsion of some 2.5 million ethnic Germans from the country.
The Republicans and Communists see the declaration as a betrayal of Czech interests, and tried in vain to block its approval by parliament earlier this month.

Sladek's party won eight percent of the popular vote in last year's lower house elections. Sladek himself was convicted of assaulting a public official and disobedience last year and was given a 10-month suspended sentence.

Two other Republican deputies, Josef Krejza and Rudolf Smucr, were also stripped of their immunity on Thursday. They may face charges for disrupting a Czech-German memorial meeting in the former Nazi concentration camp at Terezin in 1994.
